column1: Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the anus or lower part of the rectum.
If a blood clot forms in an external hemorrhoid, it can be very painful (thrombosed external hemorrhoid).
Most of the time, a health care provider can often diagnose hemorrhoids simply looking at the rectal area.

Treatments for hemorrhoids include: - Over-the-counter corticosteroid (for example, cortisone) creams to help reduce pain and swelling - Hemorrhoid creams with lidocaine to help reduce pain - Stool softeners help reduce straining and constipation Things you can do to reduce itching include: - Apply witch hazel to the area with a cotton swab.
If office treatment is not enough, some type of surgery may be necessary, such as removal of the hemorrhoids (hemorrhoidectomy).
These procedures are generally used for people with severe bleeding or prolapse who have not responded to other therapy.
Constipation, straining during bowel movements, and sitting on the toilet too long raise your risk for hemorrhoids.
